nodes.bodyText: Maybe not for this PR, but it seems that it may be very useful to formalize where record stores live in the keyspace (so that a directory "knows" that is contains record stores)...but, I guess for this to really be useful, then the directory should also have some way to describe how to find the metadata for the stores under it.  Anyway, just thinking out loud.
This and getIndexFromSubspaceKey should probably document that they throw a MetaDataException if the object specified is not found in the meta-data.

If I understand the implementation correctly, is the idea that users will extend this class and provide their own implementation of getRecordStoreMetaData and isRecordStoreLeaf? It might be good to clarify that, though this class is maybe a tad experimental for too much documentation.
Yes. I added Javadoc to that effect on those two methods.

Hm, we have a few places that we try and rendezvous the tuple we see with a key expression, but they're all a little scattershot. I think having this is here is probably fine, though perhaps when some of the new planner changes make that easier, it would be good to switch to that, or something.
Yes, agreed. But that feels outside the scope of this branch.
Why is this UNRESOLVED rather than following the same logic as in resolvePrimaryKey?

Absent some new protocol in the factory / maintainer, this class would need to know for each index type how the keys it uses correspond to the root expression.
For example, a time-window leaderboard has a leaderboard index before the group starts.
Is it worth doing for, like, VALUE?

I suppose there could be a method on the factory (the maintainer needs a record store and I'm not sure making one from the example path is legit) that returned a list of key expression, defaulting to normalizing the root expression. Aggregate indexes could return just the group and leaderboard could prepend a leaderboard id field.

Yeah, I think maybe having a method on the factory is the right choice at some point. I believe there's some possibility that something like that will come out of the planner work, in order to accommodate producing some IR based on the index definition. I could also see us wanting to do VALUE indexes sooner rather than later, but maybe not yet.

Would it also make sense to have a case INDEX_STATE_SPACE that got the index from the name (instead of the subspace key)? Or do we not want to do that to protect against that changing because of how #514 could be resolved?
Yes. Also, since the current value is the name of the index, resolving it isn't so important. It will display more or less correctly just as an unresolved value.
